meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to establish the Administrative Appeals Board for the purpose of hearing appeals against certain administrative decisions, to provide for the powers and procedure of the Board, and for related matters.

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Administrative Appeals Board Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: appellant (上訴人) means a person who initiates an appeal;
Board (委員會) means the Administrative Appeals Board established under section 5;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person appointed as Chairman of the Board under section 6(1)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person presiding at an appeal;

section.def: Deputy Chairman (副主席) means a person appointed as Deputy Chairman of the Board under section 6(1)(b);
parties to the appeal (上訴當事人) means the appellant, the respondent and any other person who is bound by the decision appealed against;
respondent (答辯人) means a person whose decision has been appealed against;
Secretary (秘書) means the Secretary to the Board appointed under section 7.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Ordinances mentioned in column 2 of the Schedule in relation to any decision of the description mentioned in column 3; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other decision in respect of which an appeal lies to the Board.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order, amend the Schedule. (Amended 59 of 1999 s. 3)
An order made under subsection (1) shall be published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: Without affecting the generality of subsection (1), the power of the Chief Executive in Council to amend the Schedule shall include a power— (Amended 59 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to delete an Ordinance from the Schedule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to add an Ordinance to the Schedule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to amend an Ordinance mentioned in the Schedule;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to amend an Ordinance at the same time that it is added to the Schedule;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of any amendment of the description mentioned in paragraph (c) or (d), to amend that Ordinance so as to, and only so as to—

subparagraph.content: substitute the Board for any person to whom an appeal may be made under or by virtue of that Ordinance;

subparagraph.leadIn: provide that any person bound by a decision shall be furnished with a statement in writing which sets out—

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the policy, if any, relied upon by the person who made the decision when the decision was made;
prescribe or, not prescribe a period within which an appeal may be made;

provide that a decision that is appealed against shall be suspended in its operation as from the day on which notice of the appeal is lodged with the Secretary under this Ordinance until such appeal is disposed of, withdrawn or abandoned unless the advice or notice of the decision given to any person bound by the decision is accompanied by a statement in writing to the effect that, in the opinion of the person who made the decision, such suspension would be contrary to the public interest;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: for the purposes of section 22(5), to add a note to the Schedule or to amend or repeal any note mentioned in it.

subsection.content: An order under this section may contain such incidental, consequential, supplemental and transitional provisions as may be necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the order.
There shall be a board called the Administrative Appeals Board.
The functions of the Board are to hear and determine any appeal duly made to the Board.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of hearing any appeal the members of the Board shall comprise—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chairman or a Deputy Chairman who shall preside; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 of the persons from the panel referred to in section 6(2) as the Secretary may appoint for that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive shall appoint from among persons who are qualified for appointment as District Judges under section 5 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Chairman of the Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 1, or more than 1, Deputy Chairman of the Board.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive shall appoint a panel of persons whom he considers suitable for appointment as members of the Board.
Subject to subsection (5), a person appointed as Chairman or Deputy Chairman or to the panel of persons, shall be appointed for a term of 3 years but may be reappointed.
An appointment under this section shall be notified in the Gazette.
Any person appointed under this section may resign by notice in writing to the Chief Executive.
The remuneration, if any, of the Chairman, any Deputy Chairman and members of the Board shall be determined by the Chief Executive.
There shall be a Secretary to the Board who shall be appointed by the Chief Executive. (Amended 59 of 1999 s. 3)

The Chairman may give to the Secretary such directions as he thinks fit with respect to the exercise of the Secretary’s functions under this Ordinance, either generally or in any particular case; and the Secretary shall comply with any direction so given.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Provision where Chairman, Deputy Chairman or member absent

subsection.content: If, for any period, the Chairman is precluded by illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause from exercising his functions, the Chief Executive may appoint any Deputy Chairman to act as Chairman and as such to exercise and perform all the functions of the Chairman during that period. (Amended 59 of 1999 s. 3)

If, for any period, a Deputy Chairman presiding at an appeal or a person appointed by the Secretary under section 5(3)(b) to hear an appeal is precluded by illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause from exercising his functions, the Secretary may appoint any Deputy Chairman or, as the case may be, any other person from the panel referred to in section 6(2) to act in his place and in so acting, to exercise and perform all the functions of the Deputy Chairman so presiding or of that person, during that period.
The hearing of an appeal may, with the consent of the appellant and of the respondent, continue notwithstanding a change in the membership of the Board.

If the term of appointment of the Chairman or a Deputy Chairman presiding at an appeal or of any person appointed by the Secretary under section 5(3)(b) expires during the hearing of any appeal, the Chairman or such Deputy Chairman or such person may continue to hear the appeal until the appeal is determined.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Appeals to the Board
section.leadIn: Any person who may appeal to the Board under a provision of an Ordinance and wishes to do so shall lodge with the Secretary a notice of appeal in such form and manner as the Chairman may determine— (Amended 23 of 2002 s. 13)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case where a period within which an appeal may be made is prescribed by or by virtue of any Ordinance, within that period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case where no such period is prescribed, within 28 days after receiving notice of the decision.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Secretary to serve notice of appeal on respondent
section.leadIn: The Secretary shall serve a copy of a notice lodged with him under section 9 on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the respondent within 14 days after a notice of appeal is so lodged, or such longer period as the Chairman, on application, may allow in any particular case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person, other than the appellant, who appears to the Secretary to be a person who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is bound by the decision appealed against; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: before the decision appealed against was made, had made representations to the respondent in relation to the subject-matter of that decision,

paragraph.continued: within 28 days after a notice of appeal is so lodged, or such longer period as the Chairman, on application, may allow in any particular case.

subsection.leadIn: The respondent shall, within 14 days after the service upon him of a copy of a notice of appeal under section 10, inform the Secretary in writing of the name and address of any person, other than the appellant, who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is bound by the decision appealed against; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: before the decision appealed against was made, had made representations to the respondent in relation to the subject-matter of that decision.

subsection.leadIn: A copy of a notice of appeal served under section 10 may be accompanied by an order of the Chairman, made in such form as the Chairman may determine, that the respondent shall within 28 days after the service upon him of a copy of notice of appeal under section 10 lodge with the Secretary, the appellant and any person of the description mentioned in subsection (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a statement in writing relating to the decision that sets out—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the reasons for the decision to which the appeal relates;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the policy, if any, relied upon by the respondent when such decision was made;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the particulars of any evidence or other thing considered and relied upon by the respondent when such decision was made;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the findings on material questions of fact relating to the decision;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: whether or not the appellant was made aware of the matters referred to in subparagraphs (i) to (iv) when such decision was made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a description of every document or part of a document that is in the possession or under the control of the respondent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: which is considered by him to relate to the appeal;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in respect of which he wishes to claim privilege as to disclosure,

subsection.continued: and the respondent shall, subject to section 14, comply with such order.

subsection.leadIn: Where a statement is lodged under subsection (2)(a) and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the Board starts to hear the appeal, the Chairman; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the Board starts to hear the appeal, the Board,

subsection.continued: considers that the statement does not contain adequate information, the Chairman or the Board, as the case may be, may order the respondent to serve on the appellant and any person of the description mentioned in subsection (1)(a), and to lodge with the Secretary within the time specified in the order, such other information as he or it may specify and the respondent shall, subject to section 14, comply with such order.

subsection.leadIn: Where, after the end of the period of 28 days mentioned in subsection (2) and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before the Board starts to hear the appeal, the Chairman; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the Board starts to hear the appeal, the Board,

subsection.continued: is of the opinion that a particular document described in a statement lodged under subsection (2)(b) or a document included in a particular class of documents and so described may be relevant to the appeal and a copy of that document has not been lodged with the Secretary by the respondent, the Chairman or the Board, as the case may be, may serve on the respondent a notice in writing stating that he or it is of that opinion and ordering the respondent to lodge with the Board, within the time specified in the notice, a copy of that document if it is in the possession or under the control of the respondent and the respondent shall, subject to section 14, comply with such order.

subsection.content: If any of the parties to the appeal requires further particulars from any of the other parties, he may, with the approval of the Chairman, within 14 days after the service on him by the Secretary of a copy of the notice of appeal under section 10 or such longer period as the Chairman, on application, may allow in any particular case, serve notice on such of the other parties specifying the further particulars required, and such of the other parties shall, subject to section 14, within 14 days after notice is served under this section or such longer period as the Chairman, on application, may allow in any particular case, furnish such particulars and lodge a copy of such particulars with the Chairman.
A notice served under this section shall have effect as if it were a lawful order, requirement or direction of the Chairman.

Any of the parties to the appeal may, with the approval of the Chairman, at any time serve notice on any of the other parties to produce any document relating to the appeal for his inspection and to permit him to take copies thereof and such of the other parties shall, subject to section 14, within 14 days after the notice is served, or such longer period as the Chairman, on application, may allow in any particular case, so produce and permit.
A notice served under this section shall have effect as if it were a lawful order, requirement or direction of the Chairman.

subsection.leadIn: A respondent shall, for the purposes of an appeal, have the same privileges in respect of disclosure of information, particulars and documents as if the proceedings were proceedings before a court of law; and the Board may, on the application of the appellant or of any person of the description mentioned in section 11(1)(a), give directions relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure to the appellant or to any such person of any information, matter or particular referred to in section 11 or 12; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provision or the production to the appellant or to any such person of a document or part of a document or a copy of a document or a copy of part of a document referred to in section 11 or 13; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the inspection by the appellant or by any such person of any such document, copy or part.

subsection.leadIn: An appellant and any person of the description mentioned in section 11(1)(a) shall, for the purposes of an appeal, have the same privileges in respect of disclosure of information, particulars and documents as if the proceedings were proceedings before a court of law; and the Board may, on the application of any of the parties to the appeal, give directions relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure to any such party of any information, matter or particular referred to in section 12; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provision or the production to any such party of a document or part of a document or a copy of a document or a copy of part of a document referred to in section 13; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the inspection by any such party of any such document, copy or part.

subsection.content: The Board shall not give directions under this section without affording the party in respect of whom the directions are to be given an opportunity to make representations to it.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, the question, in any particular case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as to whether the Board should give directions under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the Board gives directions, as to whether those directions were properly given,

subsection.continued: shall be a question of law.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Evidence on summons
section.content: Any of the parties to an appeal may at any time, by application in such form as the Chairman may determine, request the Board to issue a notice in writing to any person named in the application requiring him to appear before the Board to give evidence and to produce any document relating to the appeal that is in his possession or under his control.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Date, time and place of hearing
section.content: Where notice of appeal is lodged, the Secretary shall fix the date, time and place of the hearing of the appeal so as to enable the hearing to commence as soon as is reasonably practicable and shall, not less than 28 days before the date so fixed, serve on the parties to the appeal notice of the date, time and place in such form as the Chairman may determine.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Hearings to be in public except in special circumstances

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the hearing of an appeal to the Board shall be in public.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Board hearing an appeal, after consulting the parties to the appeal, is satisfied that it is desirable to do so, it may by order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct that a hearing or part of a hearing shall take place in private and give directions as to the persons who may be present; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give directions prohibiting or restricting the publication or disclosure to some or all of the parties to the appeal, or to some or all of the persons who may be present, of evidence given before the Board or of any matter contained in any document lodged with the Board or received in evidence by the Board, whether or not it has given directions under section 14 in respect of any such evidence, matter or document.

subsection.content: In the making of an order under subsection (2), the Board, without affecting the generality of that subsection, shall in determining whether or not it is desirable to make an order, take into account any views of the parties to the appeal, including the private interests of and any claim as to privilege by any of those parties.
For the purposes of this section, any question in relation to a claim by any party as to privilege shall be a question of law.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Appearance before Board
section.content: The parties to an appeal may appear and be present at the hearing of the appeal and may make representations or be represented either by a barrister or a solicitor or, with the approval of the Secretary, by any other person authorized by any of the parties in writing. The respondent may be represented by a legal officer within the meaning of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87).

subsection.content: The appellant may abandon the whole or any part of the appeal by notice in writing lodged with the Secretary.
When lodging a notice under subsection (1), the appellant shall at the same time serve a copy of such notice on the other parties to the appeal.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Failure of appellant to attend hearing

subsection.leadIn: If on the day and time fixed for the hearing of the appeal the appellant fails to attend the hearing or fails to make representations either in person or by counsel or a solicitor or by some other person, the Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if satisfied that the appellant’s failure to attend was due to sickness or any other reasonable cause, postpone or adjourn the hearing for such period as it thinks fit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceed to hear the appeal; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by order dismiss the appeal.

subsection.content: Where the appeal is dismissed by the Board under subsection (1)(c) the appellant may, within 28 days after the making of the order for dismissal, by notice in writing lodged with the Secretary, apply to the Board to review the order and the Board may, if satisfied that the appellant’s failure to attend the hearing was due to sickness or any other reasonable cause, set aside the order for dismissal.
When lodging a notice under subsection (2), the appellant shall at the same time serve a copy of such notice on the other parties to the appeal.
The hearing of an appeal to the Board may be conducted in the English or Chinese language or both as the Board thinks fit.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any party to an appeal or any person authorized by any party under section 18 to appear before the Board may address the Board in any language;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any witness testifying before the Board may testify in any language.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of an appeal, the Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to this Ordinance and to rules made by the Chairman under section 30 determine its own procedure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: receive and consider any material, whether by way of oral evidence, written statements, documents or otherwise, whether or not such material would be admissible in evidence in civil or criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by notice in writing signed by the Secretary, require any person to attend before it at any hearing and to give evidence and produce documents;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: administer oaths and affirmations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: examine on oath, affirmation or otherwise any person attending before it and require such person to answer all questions put by or with the consent of the Board;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: determine the manner in which the material referred to in paragraph (b) shall be received;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: with the consent of the parties to the appeal, determine the appeal without an oral hearing on the basis of written submissions only;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: if it appears to the Board that the respondent has reversed the decision appealed against, determine the appeal summarily in favour of the appellant without a hearing and without calling on anyone to attend or to appear before it;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: adjourn the determination of any appeal as it may deem fit;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), confirm, vary or reverse the decision that is appealed against or substitute therefor such other decision or make such other order as it may think fit;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: subject to section 22, make an award to any of the parties to the appeal of such sum, if any, in respect of the costs of and relating to the appeal;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: pay an allowance for the expenses of any witness summoned under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: ancillary to the powers conferred by this section; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: reasonably necessary for the discharge of its functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The Board, in the exercise of its powers under subsection (1)(j), shall have regard to any statement of policy lodged by the respondent with the Secretary under section 11(2)(a)(ii), if it is satisfied that, at the time of the making of the decision being the subject of the appeal, the appellant was or could reasonably have been expected to be aware of the policy.

The Board, on the determination of any appeal, may order that the case being the subject of the appeal as so determined be sent back to the respondent for the consideration by the respondent of such matter as the Board may order.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Provision relating to costs and witness expenses

subsection.leadIn: The Board shall only make an award as to costs under section 21(1)(k)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against an appellant, if it is satisfied that he has conducted his case in a frivolous or vexatious manner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: against any other party to the appeal, if it is satisfied that in all the circumstances of the case it would be unjust and inequitable not to do so.

subsection.content: Any sum awarded under section 21(1)(k) to any of the parties to the appeal shall be a debt due to those parties from such of the other parties to the appeal as the Board may order and be enforceable as a civil debt; and any sum payable by a public officer in right of the Government of Hong Kong or any public body or body established by or by virtue of any enactment shall, subject to subsection (5), be charged on the general revenue.

Any sum payable under section 21(1)(l) as an allowance for the expenses of any witness shall be a charge against such of the parties to the appeal as the Board may order and be enforceable as a civil debt; and any sum payable by a public officer in right of the Government of Hong Kong or any public body or body established by or by virtue of any enactment shall, subject to subsection (5), be charged on the general revenue.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may assess the amount of costs to be awarded under section 21(1)(k); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order that those costs be taxed on the basis of any one of the scale of costs specified in Part I of Schedule 1 to Order 62 of the Rules of the District Court (Cap. 336 sub. leg. H), (Amended 25 of 2008 s. 18)

subsection.continued: and the Schedules to Order 62 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) shall apply to the award, taxation and recovery of costs. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any sum payable under subsection (2) or (3) by any public body or body established by or by virtue of any enactment, that is specified in a note in the Schedule for the purposes of this subsection shall not be charged on the general revenue but shall, instead, be a charge against that public body or body so specified.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Questions to be decided by majority
section.content: Every question before the Board, except a question of law, shall be determined by the opinions of the majority of members hearing the appeal. Questions of law shall be determined by the Chairman.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Case may be stated for Court of Appeal

subsection.content: The Board may, before an appeal is determined, refer any question of law arising in the appeal to the Court of Appeal for determination by way of case stated.

On the hearing of the case the Court of Appeal may amend the case or order it to be sent back to the Board for amendment in such manner as the Court of Appeal may order and the Board shall comply with such order.

The Board shall give reasons in writing for its decisions, and those reasons shall include its findings on material questions of fact and a summary of the evidence or other material on which those findings were based.
The Secretary shall serve a copy of the Board’s decision and of the reasons for its decision on the parties to the appeal.

Where the Board orders that its decision is not to come into operation until a specified date, the decision comes into operation on that date; in other cases, the decision of the Board comes into operation immediately the decision is given.

A document purporting to be a copy of a decision or order of the Board and to be certified by the Secretary to be a true copy of the decision or order is admissible in any proceedings as evidence of the decision or order.

The Chairman, Deputy Chairmen and members of the Board have, in the performance of their duties under this Ordinance, the same privileges and immunities as a judge of the Court of First Instance in civil proceedings in that court.
A witness before the Board shall be entitled to the same privileges and immunities as if he were a witness in civil proceedings in the Court of First Instance.

Notwithstanding section 9, the Chairman may, upon application in writing by a person and if satisfied that there is good cause for doing so, extend the time within which that person may appeal to the Board under this or any other Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in this Ordinance, upon application in writing by a party to an appeal to the Board and if satisfied that there is good cause for doing so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chairman may, before the Board starts to hear the appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Board may, after the Board starts to hear the appeal,

subsection.continued: extend the time within which that party is required or permitted to do anything under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The power to extend the time under subsection (1) or (2) may be exercised by the Chairman or by the Board, as the case may be, although the application for that extension is not made until after the expiration of the time to which the application relates.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Offences relating to the Board

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: refuses or fails to comply with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any lawful order, requirement or direction of the Board or the Chairman; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the requirement of any rule made by the Chairman under section 30; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disturbs or otherwise interferes with the proceedings of the Board,

section.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Giving of notices
section.content: Where this Ordinance authorizes or requires any document to be served or any notice to be given, the document may be served or the notice may be given by post.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Chairman may make rules
section.leadIn: The Chairman, with the prior approval of the Chief Justice, may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for the practice and procedure applying to proceedings before the Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: relating to the payment of allowances for expenses of witnesses under section 21(1)(l);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally for the better carrying out of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Any right of appeal subsisting immediately before the commencement of section 9 under a provision in an Ordinance amended by this Ordinance shall be treated as being a right of appeal to the Board under that provision as so amended.

Any appeal pending immediately before the commencement of section 9 under a provision in an Ordinance amended by this Ordinance shall be treated and disposed of as if it were an appeal pending to the Board under that provision as so amended.
